newsitem.title: INDIA: India's "Silicon Valley" sees software export boom.
newsitem.headline: India's "Silicon Valley" sees software export boom.

text.p: Software exports from the southern Indian state of Karnataka are expected to jump to 10 billion rupees ($280 million) in 1997/98 (April-March), more than double their level in 1996/97, a state official said on Tuesday.

"We will more than double our exports this year," Karnataka Industries Minister R.V. Deshpande told reporters in the state capital Bangalore while releasing the state's new software policy which offers a range of tax incentives to software firms.
Bangalore is nicknamed India's "Silicon Valley" because of the large number of computer and other high-technology firms. Karnataka accounts for nearly 32 percent of India's software exports.
Deshpande and the state's chief minister, J.H. Patel, are scheduled to leave for the United States on June 16 to woo foreign investment from U.S. computer companies. ($1 = 35.8 rupees)
